source_id: STP824-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_6th Volume_043_chunk2
evidence_span: The criterion for intergranular failure (the process which dominates at low local stresses) is simply a critical local iodine concentration Ig
property_name: critical iodine concentration for intergranular failure

source_id: STP824-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_6th Volume_043_chunk2
evidence_span: The criterion for the transgranular cleavage and fluting process (which dominates at high local stresses) is based on the combination of local stress and local iodine concentration

source_id: STP824-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_6th Volume_043_chunk2
evidence_span: The stress level of σ₀, C+F represents the lowest local stress at which transgranular cracking is the faster of the two processes; its value is deduced from Kiscc data on unirradiated Zircaloy

source_id: STP824-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_6th Volume_043_chunk2
evidence_span: The rupture failure criterion in the SCCIG model is a critical local strain which decreases as the degree of triaxiality (associated with increases in crack depth) increases

evidence_span: SCCIG predictions for iodine stress-corrosion crack growth rate as a function of stress intensity, hoop stress, and crack length for CWSR Zircaloy-2 at 340°C

evidence_span: For deep cracks, (dc/dt) is a unique function of K_I and at high K_I values (K_I > K_ISCC) (dc/dt) ∝ K_I⁴

Now the iodine concentration is about $4 \times 1 0 ^ { - 4 } \mathrm { k g / m } ^ { 2 }$ , which allows a temperature of greater than $4 5 0 \%$ for 1000-year failure

source_id: STP824-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_6th Volume_043_chunk8
evidence_span: Storage in an oxidizing atmosphere would reduce the SLT in two ways: (1) the stress would increase with time as the cladding is thinned by external oxidation; and (2) $c _ { 0 } / w$ would increase with time even if $c _ { 0 }$ is constant, due to the wall thinning

source_id: STP824-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_6th Volume_043_chunk8
evidence_span: the model's constants (principally $k _ { 2 }$ in Eq 1) have been optimized for accuracy in the range $c / w \leq 0 . 2$ Thus the model is not expected to be very precise in predicting behavior for $c / w$ greater than about 0.3

source_id: STP824-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_6th Volume_043_chunk8
evidence_span: the present approach forces us to impose the upper cutoff on the as-manufactured flaw size distribution at $c / w = 0 . 1 0$

source_id: STP824-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_6th Volume_043_chunk8
